授業目的:
日本の祭りは、ただの遊びと娯楽なのか、あるいはより多様な意義を有するか。本授業では、全国で年間に開催される主要な祭礼を通じて、日本文化を紹介する。授業目的は、これらの祭礼を、宗教的、文化的、社会的、経済的などの現象としてさまざまな視点から理解できることである。
今学期は、パンデミックの現状をふまえ、日本における祭りと疫病の関連、そして2020年にいくつかの重要な祭りがどのように行われたかなどに、特に注目する。
到達目標:
Students will gain a comprehensive overview and understanding of 
Japanese religious and traditional rites and their place in contemporary
 society, as well as of the issues of gender, identity, and power. The students 
will also deepen their knowledge of the Japanese history and how it 
formed various festivals.
特記事項: 【合併】総合日本学習科目（伝統行事）（CIEC）/Religious and Traditional Rites（国際学部）
関連科目: There is no prerequisite for this course but a related course would be any standard course on Japanese religion and history.
授業の概要・背景:
The course will explore the origins and significance of Japanese 
festivals, their role in preserving traditional Japanese values while 
also incorporating contemporary features and attracting tourists. We 
will pay particular attention to the elements of performance: rituals, 
processions, portable shrines, costumes, accessories, patterns of 
movement, music, food. Additionally, we will explore gender in the 
matsuri: display and affirmation of traditional ideals of femininity and
 masculinity, cross-dressing, gender fluidity, the body, models of 
gendered behavior and relations, the different roles of male and female 
community members, the increasing participation of women.
授業方法: The course combines lecture/discussion format with extensive audio-visual display. Student in-class presentations and discussions.

第3回:
New Beginning - Oshôgatsu "New Year" and Setsubun "Change of Seasons":
Oshôgatsu - history, rituals, family bonds, special food. Setsubun "Driving out the Evil" - history, rituals - mamemaki, oni-barai (tsuina), commercialization and special food, performances: masks and costumes.
第4回:
Matsuri and Gender:
The Girl's Day Festival - Hina Matsuri or Momo-no-sekku "Festival of the Peach."
The Boy's Day Festival - Tango-no-sekku or Kodomo-no-hi "Children's Day."
History, meaning, rituals, and art.
第5回:
Aoi Matsuri "Hollyhock Festival" and Jidai Matsuri "Festival of the Ages" (The Three Big Festivals in Kyoto):
Relation to Kyoto, Japanese history, and the imperial power. Elements of performance: processions, costumes, accessories, gendered bodies; display of ideals of traditional masculinity / femininity. Influence of Aoi Matsuri on Noh theatre.
第6回:
Matsuri and Geinô "Festivals and Performance":
Types of performances, intergenerational bonding, initiation into manhood, gender, local identity. Some major examples - kabuki, noh, kagura, lion dances, puppets and marionettes.
第7回:
Festivals in Okinawa and Amami Islands. Ainu Culture.
History and types, performances, gender aspects, local identities. Taketomi Island's Tanedori Festival and Amami Island Festival's sumo (shinji sumo "Sumo as Shinto Ritual"). Ainu festivals.
第8回:
Matsuri and Masculinity:
Hadaka Matsuri "Naked Festivals" and Kenka Matsuri "Fighting Festivals" - most popular examples, origins, meaning, rituals, display of the male body, homosociality and intergenerational bonding. Fertility festivals.
第10回:
Obon "Ancestors' Spirits Festival":
History, rituals, food, offerings, family bonds, bon odori "bon dances." Gozan Okuri-bi "Bonfires on Five Mountains" in Kyoto. Obon in Kyoto during the pandemic.
第11回:
Summer Festivals I:
Nagoshi-no-harae "Summer Purification Rites" and Tanabata "The Star Festival / The Lovers' Festival" - origins, meaning, changes in modern time. Special celebration in Kyoto during the pandemic.
第12回:
Summer Festivals II - Kyoto Gion Matsuri (The Three Big Festivals in Kyoto):
Origins and hostiry: relation to epidemic, significance in Kyoto culture and for local merchant class. Elements of performance: procession, costumes, accessories, art work, music, etc. Gender aspects: the all-male festival's "hyper-" and "stylized" masculinity, representation and recent inclusion of women. Gion matsuri during the pandemic.
第13回:
Influence of Gion Matsuri:
The influence of Gion matsuri on local Gion festivals in all parts of Japan, held from June to October. Comparison with Osaka Tenjin Matsuri "Festival of the Gods."

Students are expected to do the assigned readings and watch the assigned video materials in advance of class, in order to take part in the discussions.
Attendance is mandatory. In the event of illness or other absence, please notify your instructor in advance of class.
Students are required to prepare one in-class 10-minute presentation on topic related to the class content, assigned by the instructor or offered by themselves (counts as class participation 30%). Students are also required to do a final 10-minute presentation on their research paper.
Students will be given extra credit for attending individually a festival and writing one-page response paper on it. They can do their in-class presentation on that festival.
